On the right, there are many strands of the thread hanging on the tree , and there is a big loom underneath for weaving. When threads are woven together, then it becomes a fabric. It is now used to mean a â€˜passâ€™, or â€˜economyâ€™. (å¸ƒ, bu, cloth) A hand takes a long tool, and the fabric is rolled up. Someone is flattening a piece of cloth with a bat. It is used as the meaning of â€˜fabricâ€™ and â€˜flattenâ€™. (å¸‚, shi, city; market) This character meant â€˜to stopâ€™ æ­¢ (zhi=chih, stop). Below is the roll of cloth, for making clothes. Textiles were an important trading item. This cloth is sold in specific locations, at a â€˜marketâ€™ or in a â€˜cityâ€™. Looking at the character (è¡£, yi, clothing) which means a garment, we can easily discern two sleeves on both sides. One side of the collar is folded over the other. This character is applied in other characters. For example, (ä¾, yi, to depend on) is a combination of a garment (è¡£, yi) and a person who is wearing the garment. He needs to protect himself from the wind, sun, and cold with clothes. Clothes were precious and people treasured their clothes. Therefore, the symbol evolved to â€œto depend onâ€.
humanum_full_description_en:
Elaboration: The characters " clothes " on the oracle bones and the bronze inscriptions are all like the shape of a coat, in which the collar, two sleeves and placket are clearly visible, like the shape of the left and right plackets overlapping.

In addition, in ancient times, clothes were called clothes on the top and clothes on the bottom were not mixed. Moreover, the character " clothing " is an important radical of Chinese characters. When used as parts of other Chinese characters, other parts are often added between the clothes and the left and right sides of the body, as a metaphor for something to be placed in the bosom. See " ring ", " far ", " huai ", etc.

The oracle bone inscriptions are used as names of places, people, and sacrifices. Bronze inscriptions indicate a coat without a drapery: "Yi (gi) female (ru) Xuanyi", Xuanyi is a black coat. It is also used as " pawn " to indicate the end, [Dong Ge] Gui: "Yi (pawn) fights, no stunned", "pawn fight" means the end of the fight. " Clothes " and " pawns " are similar in shape. It is also read throughout as " Yin ", the name of the sacrifice, and the death of heaven: "The clothes are sacrificed to the king, and the king of Wen is not (pi)".

"Said Wen": "Clothes are in accordance with the same. The upper part is the clothes, and the lower is the clothes. The shape of the two people is like covering. All the clothes belong to the clothes."

heisig_comment:
* Used as a primitive, the additional meanings of cloak or scarf will come in handy. What has to be noted particularly are the changes in shape the kanji can undergo when it becomes an element in other kanji. In fact, it is the most volatile of all the kanji we shall treat, and for that reason deserves special attention here.
When it appears to the left, it looks like a hiragana ne (ãƒ) with an extra drop on the right, and we shall take it to mean cloak. At the bottom, when attached to the stroke immediately above it, the first two strokes (the top hat) are omitted, which we shall take to mean a scarf.
On rare occasions, the element can be torn right across the middle, with the first 2 strokes appearing at the top and the last 4 at the bottom of another primitive or cluster of primitive, in which cases we shall speak of a top hat and scarf.
And finally, of course, it can keep its original kanji shape, along with its original meaning of garment in general.
Note that when any of the above forms have something beneath them (as in frame 429), the third from final stroke is "unhooked."

Heisig constituents: garment, top hat, scarf, cloth, clothes, clothing, garment
Heisig: At the top we see the top hat, and at the bottom a pictographic representation of the folds of a garment. If you break the "4-fold" fold into 2 sets of 2 strokes, you will find it easier to remember.
* Used as a primitive, the additional meanings of cloak or scarf will come in handy. What has to be noted particularly are the changes in shape the kanji can undergo when it becomes an element in other kanji. In fact, it is the most volatile of all the kanji we shall treat, and for that reason deserves special attention here.
When it appears to the left, it looks like a hiragana ne (ãƒ) with an extra drop on the right, and we shall take it to mean cloak. At the bottom, when attached to the stroke immediately above it, the first two strokes (the top hat) are omitted, which we shall take to mean a scarf.
On rare occasions, the element can be torn right across the middle, with the first 2 strokes appearing at the top and the last 4 at the bottom of another primitive or cluster of primitive, in which cases we shall speak of a top hat and scarf.
And finally, of course, it can keep its original kanji shape, along with its original meaning of garment in general.
Note that when any of the above forms have something beneath them (as in frame 429), the third from final stroke is "unhooked."

Elaboration: The characters " clothes" on the oracle bones and the bronze inscriptions are all like the shape of a coat, in which the collar, two sleeves and placket are clearly visible, like the shape of the left and right plackets overlapping. In addition, in ancient times, clothes were called clothes on the top and clothes on the bottom were not mixed. Moreover, the character " clothing" is an important radical of Chinese characters. When used as parts of other Chinese characters, other parts are often added between the clothes and the left and right sides of the body, as a metaphor for something to be placed in the bosom. See " ring", " far", " huai", etc. The oracle bone inscriptions are used as names of places, people, and sacrifices. Bronze inscriptions indicate a coat without a drapery: "Yi (gi) female (ru) Xuanyi", Xuanyi is a black coat. It is also used as " pawn" to indicate the end, [Dong Ge] Gui: "Yi (pawn) fights, no stunned", "pawn fight" means the end of the fight. " Clothes" and " pawns" are similar in shape. It is also read throughout as " Yin", the name of the sacrifice, and the death of heaven: "The clothes are sacrificed to the king, and the king of Wen is not (pi)". "Said Wen": "Clothes are in accordance with the same. The upper part is the clothes, and the lower is the clothes. The shape of the two people is like covering. All the clothes belong to the clothes."

What people wear to cover their bodies: clothes. Clothing (zhu?). Attire. hanger. Yijin also (hu ä¿·) township.

[â‘ ]ï¼»yÄ«ï¼½
["Guangyun" Yu Xiqie, Ping Wei, Shadow. ]
(1) Tops.
(2) Refers to clothes in general.
(3) By extension, it refers to things that cover parts of the body.
(4) Things that cover the surface of utensils or natural objects.
(5) Things wrapped around pills or floating on the surface of certain foods.
(6) Refers to the robes.
(7) Refers to the feathers of birds.
(8) Refers to the frost powder on the skin, membrane and surface of the fruit.
(9) Names of sacrifices in Yin Dynasty. Refer to Wang Guowei's "A Study of the Xiangong and Xianwang Seen in GuantangjilinÂ·Yin Oracle".
(10) Through "according to".
(11) Through "Yin".
(12) Last name. There was Yi clan in Yuan Dynasty. See "Yuan History Â· Biography of Women II".

(3) Covering.

(5) Wrap or smear the surface of the object.
